name.text: Determining the Angle of a Sector.

questiontext.text:
The diagram below shows a sector of a circle with center \(\text{O}\) and radius \({@r@}\,\text{cm}\). The area of the sector is \({@Area@} \, \text{cm}^2\).

[[jsxgraph]] var brd = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { boundingbox: [-1, 8, 8, -1], axis: false, showNavigation: false, showCopyright: false }); // Centre of the circle var O = brd.create('point', [0, 0], {visible: false}); // Radius length var r = 6; // Points on the circle forming 45° sector var P = brd.create('point', [r, 0], {visible: false}); // along x-axis var Q = brd.create('point', [r*Math.cos(Math.PI/4), r*Math.sin(Math.PI/4)], {visible: false}); // Draw the 45° sector brd.create('sector', [O, P, Q], { fillColor: 'white', fillOpacity: 0.4, strokeColor: 'black' }); // Draw radii brd.create('segment', [O, P], {strokeWidth: 2}); brd.create('segment', [O, Q], {strokeWidth: 2}); // Draw arc of the sector brd.create('arc', [O, P, Q], {strokeWidth: 2}); // Angle marker brd.create('angle', [P, O, Q], {radius: 1.2, name: 'x'}); // Radius label brd.create('text', [r/2, -0.2, '{#r#} cm']); [[/jsxgraph]]

Calculate the angle subtended at the center of the circle. (Take \(\pi=\frac{22}{7}\))

\(\text{x}=\)[[input:ans1]]\(^\circ\)[[validation:ans1]]\(^\circ\)

[[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
To find the angle at the center of a sector, we use the formula:

\(\text{Area of sector} = \frac{x}{360} \times \pi r^2\)

We are given:

Area = \({@Area@}\, \text{cm}^2\), \(r = {@r@}\) cm, \(\pi = {@pi_val@}\)

Substitute the values into the formula:

\({@Area@} = \frac{x}{360} \times {@pi_val@} \times {@r@}^2\)

Calculate \({@r@}^2\):

\({@r@} \times {@r@} = {@r_square@}\)

Now the equation becomes:

\({@Area@} = \frac{x}{360} \times {@pi_val@} \times {@r_square@}\)

Multiply \(\frac{22}{7} \times {@r_square@}\):

\(\frac{22 \times {@r_square@}}{7} = {@solve_1@}\)

Now:

\({@Area@} = \frac{x}{360} \times {@solve_1@}\)

Multiply both sides by 360:

\({@Area@} \times 360 = x \times {@solve_1@}\)

\({@solve_2@}= x \times {@solve_1@}\)

Divide both sides by {@solve_1@}:

\(x = \frac{{@solve_2@}}{{@solve_1@}} = {@theta_deg@}^\circ\)

Final Answer: \(\boxed{x = {\color{blue}{@theta_deg@}^\circ}}\)
